attributes.title: Standard versus Ultrasound-guided Cannulation of the Femoral Artery in Patients Undergoing Invasive Procedures: A Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

q1.value: Standard versus Ultrasound-guided Cannulation of the Femoral Artery in Patients Undergoing Invasive Procedures: A Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

q3.value:
Access site complications are the most common periprocedural complications in patients undergoing trans-femoral diagnostic and interventional procedures and have been associated with an increased risk of morbidity and mortality, as well as costs for the health-care system. Therefore, the shift, recently observed, from femoral to radial as access of choice has been supported by the possibility to decrease such adverse events, thanks to its superficial and easily compressible nature. In this direction, several trials and observational registries have recently shown that radial access is associated with a better net clinical benefit compared to femoral access; approach that is now recommended as the first choice in the current guidelines on myocardial revascularization by the European Society of Cardiology.  
However, crossovers to trans-femoral access (TFA) still occur in about 7% of cases, because of anatomical constrictions, including the small artery size or the occurrence of radial spasm, or because of the presence of clinical conditions causing the weakness or absence of the radial pulse (i.e. cardiogenic shock, subclavian stenosis). Furthermore, procedures requiring the use of TFA because of the large-diameter delivery sheaths, such as transcatheter valve replacement or endoprosthesis implantation, are steadily increasing worldwide, thus further enlarging the number of patients requiring TFA. 
Because the success and freedom from complications are generally related to the case-volume, concerns have been raised about the fact that the new generation of interventional cardiologists, experienced primarily with the radial approach, may become less practiced at performing procedures using TFA; a circumstance that potentially increases the risk of procedural complications. 
In this scenario, adopting ultrasound-guided cannulation (UGC) of the femoral artery may potentially decrease such adverse events. Published in the 2010 by Seto and Colleagues, the Femoral Arterial Access With Ultrasound Trial (FAUST) trial randomized 1,004 patients undergoing TFA invasive procedures to UGC or standard approach and showed the superiority of USG in the rates of successful cannulation (primary endpoint), and a slightly, but significant, reduction in vascular complications. In the last years several trials and observational registries have been published evaluating the effectiveness of USG in patients undergoing percutaneous invasive interventions, providing new insights in a context of new technologies and invasive procedures such as percutaneous treatment of valvular interventions or the treatment of complex coronary lesions, that may require larger guide-catheters as well as the use of hemodynamic support devices.

q4.value: Wherever  ultrasound-guided versus standard cannulation of the femoral artery decrease the risk of access site complications compared to the standard approaches in patients undergoing percutaneous cardiovascular intervention (PCvI).

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This met analysis will include all randomized clinical trials evaluating the effectiveness of ultrasound guided cannulation  compared to standard approaches in patients undergoing percutaneous cardiovascular intervention (PCvI). PCvI is defined as thranscatheter interventional procedures using femoral artery as route of access, including percutaneous coronary intervention, aortic valve replacement, aortic endoprosthesis implantation, or intervention of peripheral artery districts.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: MEDLINE, EMBASE, Scopus and oral presentations from the latest international conferences for papers published or posted until May 30, 2019 will be used for systematic research. Studies included in the analysis will be limited to randomized clinical trials (RCTs) enrolling patients undergoing invasive procedure using TFA. Exclusion criteria are: observational studies, single arm pilot studies, non-English language studies, editorials, letters, expert opinions, case reports/series. The following key words are used for the search: femoral artery, ultrasonography, ultrasound, interventional, endovascular, cannulation, catheter, catheterization, angiography, percutaneous, and trial. Two investigators will independently evaluate studies for eligibility and any discrepancies resolved by a third reviewer. Risk for bias for each trial for both the primary and secondary endpoints will be evaluated using the Cochrane tool as described by Higgins et al

q13.value: This is a study level meta analysis that will include all randomized clinical trials evaluation the safety and efficacy profile of ultrasound guided cannulation of femoral artery compared to standard approaches in patients undergoing percutaneous cardiovascular interventions. Therefore, sample size will depend on the amount of the studies eventually selected for the analysis.

question.value:
The primary efficacy outcome will be the success rate of artery cannulation at the first attempt. Secondary efficacy endpoints are the access time and number of attempts. 
Primary safety endpoint is the rate of in-hospital vascular complications. 
Secondary endpoints will be the rate of in-hospital major bleeding, access site hematoma, pseudoaneurysm, venepuncture and retroperitoneal hematoma.

We will estimate risk ratios (RRs) and standardized mean differences (SMDs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for all available categorical and continuous variables, respectively. During data extraction, continuous variables reported as medians with low and high ends of the range or interquartile range will be converted to means and standard deviations (SDs) according to the method of Wan et al (1). Heterogeneity among trials for each outcome will be estimated with chi-square tests and quantified with I2 statistics (less than 25% represented mild heterogeneity, 25–50% represented moderate heterogeneity, and higher than 50% represented severe heterogeneity) (2). The primary analytic method will be random-effect models, according to Mantel-Haenszel. Publication bias will be assessed by means of visual estimation of a Funnel plot. A sequential analysis for the main outcomes will be also assessed to evaluate the magnitude and importance of each study. We deemed p values <0.05 as significant. RevMan (version 5.3) were used for the statistical analyses.

1) Wan X, Wang W, Liu J, Tong T. Estimating the sample mean and standard deviation from the sample size, median, range and/or interquartile range. BMC Med Res Methodol 2014;14:135.
2) Higgins JP, Thompson SG, Deeks JJ, Altman DG. Measuring inconsistency in meta-analyses. BMJ 2003;327:557-60.

attributes.title: Technology-assisted supplemental work, unfinished tasks and sleep

q1.value: Technology-assisted supplemental work, unfinished tasks and sleep: the moderating role of problem solving pondering.

q4.value:
H1: Daily TASW is negatively related to daily unfinished tasks. 
H2: Daily unfinished tasks are negatively related to daily sleep (quality and quantity). 
H3: Daily unfinished tasks mediate the relationship of daily TASW and daily sleep (quality and quantity) such that more daily TASW is related to less daily unfinished tasks which in turn is associated with better daily sleep (quality and quantity)

H4: Problem solving pondering moderates the negative relationship of daily TASW and daily unfinished tasks such that the relationship is stronger under conditions of high problem solving pondering.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study consists of multiple measurement waves. First, an online baseline questionnaire assesses demographics and basic levels of within-person variables. After that, participants fill in a daily diary booklet for five consecutive workdays twice a day.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants are recruited using the private and professional network of the first author. Additionally, participants are asked to spread the study flyer to acquire additional participants. Inclusion criteria for participation are the following: currently employed with at least 20 working hours per week, at least three years of work experience, and regular use of technological devices for work puposes after hours (at least once a week). As a thank you for participation, participants will have the chance to get an individual profile on different personality variables as well as take part in an online webinar on work-life-balance. Additionally, they can receive a presentation with the study results and take part in a lottery raffling a 50€ Amazon voucher. Time span for data collection is September 2019 until February 2020.

q13.value: The targeted sample size is 100 participants.

question.value: Predictor variable: Daily technology-assisted supplemental work after hours is assessed quantitatively by asking participants how much time (in hours and minutes) they have spent engaging in TASW after hours the respective day. Mediator: Unfinished tasks are measured using three items of the unfinished tasks scale developed by Syrek et al. (2016). Items are rated on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Outcome: Quality and quantity of daily sleep are assessed with two questions from the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (Buysse et al., 1989). Participants are asked to rate the quality of last nights sleep on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (very poor) to 5 (very good). Additionally, they specify the number of hours slept the previous night. Moderator: Problem solving pondering is assessed with three items of the work-related rumination scale (Cropley et al., 2012), adjusted to daily level. Items are rated on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).

Path analysis in the multilevel structural equation modeling framework in Mplus 7 (Muthén and Muthén, 2017) will be applied. Thereby, daily TASW is the predictor variable, whereas daily unfinished tasks function as mediator. Outcome variables are daily sleep quality and quantity. The first stage moderator is problem solving pondering.

attributes.title: Multi-lab replication: antisaccade task as the depleting task
Medication self-management frameworks:  A scoping review of the literature
attributes.description: A scoping review protocol for medication self-management frameworks

q1.value: Medication self-management frameworks: A scoping review of the literature

q2.value: Lauren Cadel, Amanda Everall, Sara Guilcher, Kadesha James

q3.value:
From a preliminary scan of the literature, it was identified that many medication management frameworks are lacking components of self-management, especially from the patient or caregiver’s perspective. In our previous narrative review, the majority of medication management frameworks are focused on patient adherence to a specific medication regimen. The purpose of this scoping review is to identify what frameworks currently exist on medication self-management. Understanding how other research has conceptualized self-management within medication management will help inform what has been done, how previous work aligns with self-management theory for populations with chronic conditions.  Depending on the extent, scope and depth of the research identified, we may identify recommendations for the need to develop a patient-centred framework for medication self-management.

Research Question: What is reported in the literature on patient- or person-level medication management frameworks or models within the context of self-management?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Scoping review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Four electronic databases will be searched: MEDLINE (Ovid interface), EMBASE (Ovid interface), CINAHL (EBSCO interface) and Cochrane Library. Grey literature will be searched on TSpace, the World Health Organization and the websites of relevant professional organizations/ associations.

Search terms: The following terms will be searched using Boolean operators, truncations, wild cards and proximity operators: medication therapy management, medication adherence, medication effectiveness, medication appropriateness, model, framework, self-management, self-efficacy, self-education, self-monitor. The full strategy can be requested from the authors.

Inclusion criteria: For inclusion, articles will be required to meet the following criteria: (1) peer reviewed or grey literature, (2) a framework or model for medication self-management and (3) published from 2000 to current. 

Exclusion criteria: If articles meet any of the following criteria, they will be excluded: (1) books, book chapters, opinion pieces, editorials, (2) focus on theories or concepts related to medication self-management, without a concrete process or framework that can be used to guide medication self-management and (3) articles published before 2000. 

Screening Processes: Fifty titles and abstracts will be screened by the core research team (four reviewers), who will then test their percent agreement, if the reviewers have good agreement (greater than 80%), the remaining titles and abstracts will be split evenly to be screened. All disagreements will be discussed in-person until a consensus is reached. The full-text article screen will follow the same process. 

Data extraction: A data extraction form will be developed and tested by the research team prior to the extraction of any data from the included articles. Data will be extracted by a single person in order to ensure consistency of the data being extracted. Extracted data will contain the following information: study characteristics, population characteristics, framework characteristics, principles of self-management integrated in the frameworks/models, study outcomes (if applicable) and conclusions.
Not applicable

Data extraction variables: Extracted data will contain the following information: study characteristics, population characteristics, framework characteristics, principles of self-management integrated in the frameworks/models, study outcomes (if applicable) and conclusions.
Not applicable

q23.value: If there is incomplete or missing data, we will contact the corresponding author to request the missing information. If the data cannot be retrieved, the missing value will be reported as ‘not reported’.

q25.value: No additional information to be included.

attributes.title: Relationship between material hardship and its developmental timing on adolescence white matter structure

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Relationship between material hardship and developmental timing on adolescence white matter structure.

other.value:
During this pre-registration period, data collection has been completed but no analyses as written up here have been conducted. However, raw data been pre-processed in preparation. The following computation have been completed prior to pre-registration: Cumulative material hardship scores per subject; material hardship scores at age 1, 3, 5, 9, 15 per subject; white matter connectivity from amygdala as seed and PFC regions BA 9, 10, 11, 24, 25, 32, 47 as target regions. 

Additionally, diffusion MRI raw data has also undergone pre-processing steps (conversion, quality control check, fitting, and registration) prior to registration. However, white matter connectivity between hippocampus-PFC and hippocampus-amygdala have not been mapped and will be computed using similar probabilistic tractography method conducted for amygdala-PFC white matter connectivity.

sample.value: Data collection has been completed prior to pre-registration. Out of 237 MRI sample of adolescents aged 15-17 years old, 196 diffusion data survived correction and pre-processing. The sample was recruited from the longitudinal Fragile Families and Childhood Wellbeing Study (FFCWS) sites in Detroit, MI, Toledo, OH, and Chicago, IL. The final sample may be smaller than stated to account for outliers that may be identified during subsequent MRI processing and data analyses.

analyses.value:
To address aim 1, regression analyses will be performed to test how cumulative material hardship relate to hippocampus-PFC, amygdala-PFC, and hippocampus-amygdala white matter circuitry in adolescence. 

To address aim 2, regression analyses will be performed to test how developmental timing of material hardship may be related to hippocampus-PFC, amygdala-PFC, and hippocampus-amygdala white matter circuitry in adolescence. Material hardship score at each age (1, 3, 5, 9, 15) will be added into one multi-regression model to test which developmental age will be most significant to predict white matter connectivity. 
Additionally, we will also group material hardship scores into early childhood (age 1 and 3), middle childhood (5 and 9), and adolescent (15) to test which development age group will be most significant to predict white matter connectivity. 

Following these main effect analyses, we will conduct additional analyses to control for factors related to sampling differences (FF birth city) and characteristics of the adolescent (gender, race, pubertal development/age). 
These covariates are as follows: birth city (Detroit, Toledo, other); self-report race/ethnicity (AA, Hispanic vs. Other; Caucasian/White vs. Other); gender (male, female); pubertal development measured with the Pubertal Development Scale. 

Subsequent regression analyses will be conducted to include the following additional covariates in sequential manner: maternal education at birth; marital status and family structure at birth; current stress; internalizing symptoms.

outliers.value:
Diffusion data has been corrected for intra-volume motion using slice-to-volume correction. The slices were marked as outlier if they had an average intensity of four or more standard deviations lower than predicted using eddy’s Gaussian process model. These outlier slices were replaced with model predictions and subjects with more than 5% of outlier slices were excluded (N=1). Across included participants, 0.00% to 4.35% of the slices were replaced (median = 0.43%). Ten images with most replaced slices were visually inspected to ensure no additional abnormal artefacts were introduced during preprocessing. 

In the case of extreme outliers (less than Q1-IQR*2.2 or greater than Q3+IQR2.2), the model will be run without the potential outliers to see if they impact the regression coefficients (Hoaglin & Iglewicz, 1987).

hypothesis.value:
Aim 1. Examine the association between cumulative material hardship (MH) and white matter circuitry in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 1a: Higher level of cumulative MH across infancy, childhood, and adolescence will be associated with reduced white matter connectivity between the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex (PFC) in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 1b: Higher level of cumulative MH across infancy, childhood, and adolescence will be associated with reduced white matter connectivity between the amygdala and PFC in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 1c: Higher level of cumulative MH across infancy, childhood, and adolescence will be associated with reduced white matter connectivity between the hippocampus and amygdala in adolescence. 

Aim 2. Examine the association between developmental timing of MH on white matter circuitry. 
Hypothesis 2a: Variation in MH across developmental ages (1, 3, 5, 9, and 15 years) will relate to hippocampus-PFC in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 2b: Variation in MH across developmental ages (1, 3, 5, 9, and 15 years) will relate to amygdala-PFC circuitry in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 2c: Variation in MH across developmental ages (1, 3, 5, 9, and 15 years) will relate to hippocampus-amygdala circuitry in adolescence.

To address aim 2, regression analyses will be performed to test how developmental timing of material hardship may be related to hippocampus-PFC, amygdala-PFC, and hippocampus-amygdala white matter circuitry in adolescence. Material hardship score at each age (1, 3, 5, 9, 15) will be added into one multi-regression model to test which developmental age will be most significant to predict white matter connectivity. 
Additionally, we will also group material hardship scores into early childhood (age 1 and 3), middle childhood (5 and 9), and adolescent (15) to test which development age group will be most significant to predict white matter connectivity. 

Following these main effect analyses, we will conduct additional analyses to control for factors related to sampling differences (FF birth city) and characteristics of the adolescent (gender, race, pubertal development/age). 
These covariates are as follows: birth city (Detroit, Toledo, other); self-report race/ethnicity (AA, Hispanic vs. Other; Caucasian/White vs. Other); gender (male, female); pubertal development measured with the Pubertal Development Scale. 

Subsequent regression analyses will be conducted to include the following additional covariates in sequential manner: maternal education at birth; marital status and family structure at birth; current stress; internalizing symptoms.
registration_responses.outliers:
Diffusion data has been corrected for intra-volume motion using slice-to-volume correction. The slices were marked as outlier if they had an average intensity of four or more standard deviations lower than predicted using eddy’s Gaussian process model. These outlier slices were replaced with model predictions and subjects with more than 5% of outlier slices were excluded (N=1). Across included participants, 0.00% to 4.35% of the slices were replaced (median = 0.43%). Ten images with most replaced slices were visually inspected to ensure no additional abnormal artefacts were introduced during preprocessing. 

In the case of extreme outliers (less than Q1-IQR*2.2 or greater than Q3+IQR2.2), the model will be run without the potential outliers to see if they impact the regression coefficients (Hoaglin & Iglewicz, 1987).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Aim 1. Examine the association between cumulative material hardship (MH) and white matter circuitry in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 1a: Higher level of cumulative MH across infancy, childhood, and adolescence will be associated with reduced white matter connectivity between the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex (PFC) in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 1b: Higher level of cumulative MH across infancy, childhood, and adolescence will be associated with reduced white matter connectivity between the amygdala and PFC in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 1c: Higher level of cumulative MH across infancy, childhood, and adolescence will be associated with reduced white matter connectivity between the hippocampus and amygdala in adolescence. 

Aim 2. Examine the association between developmental timing of MH on white matter circuitry. 
Hypothesis 2a: Variation in MH across developmental ages (1, 3, 5, 9, and 15 years) will relate to hippocampus-PFC in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 2b: Variation in MH across developmental ages (1, 3, 5, 9, and 15 years) will relate to amygdala-PFC circuitry in adolescence. 
Hypothesis 2c: Variation in MH across developmental ages (1, 3, 5, 9, and 15 years) will relate to hippocampus-amygdala circuitry in adolescence.

attributes.title: Do Financial Incentives Motivate Effort and Creativity?

q1.value: Do Financial Incentives Motivate Effort and Creativity?

q2.value: Florian Trippler, Wasilios Hariskos, Manfred Königstein

q3.value: Although financial incentives are considered the most common form of motivation in the field of work, the effect is anything but clear when it comes to creativity. Thus, this experiment aims to evaluate whether financial incentives for tasks of both pure effort and creativity lead to better results in the respective task.

q4.value: Three Hypotheses will be tested: A) Financial Incentives lead to better results in effort tasks. B) Financial incentives cause less improvement in creative tasks than in the effort tasks. C) Results in the effort task do not show significant correlation with results in the creativity task, if it is controlled for the payment regime (fixed or variable payment).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will be a lab experiment with two treatment groups. One group receives a fixed sum regardless of the outcome in both creativity and effort task. The other group receives financial incentives. This means that the more points they score in both tasks the more money they earn. Participants will be aware to which group they belong but they will not know about the group of the other participants. Since all the subjects work on both creativity and effort tasks we have a mixed design with aspects of both a between and a within-design. Counterbalancing is required to prevent order effects. Thus, half of the participants start with an effort task, while the other half start with a creativity task.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be collected by using a pool of students at the University of Erfurt who voluntarily registered for potential participation at experiments in the eLab of the University. Participants will be paid 10€ per hour on average. The group with a fixed payment gets 10€ for participation. The incentives for the other group are selected in such a fashion that they will earn approximately 10€ per hour as well, with significant variance between the individuals of course. The only requirement for participants is to be a German native speaker. Furthermore, participants will be excluded who have prior knowledge about some of the creativity tasks.

q13.value: The target sample size is 60 participants due to limited funding since the study is only a project for a master dissertation. 60 Participants will allow for four sessions of 15 participants each with 30 participants for each treatment.

question.value: As mentioned before, the focus of the analysis is on the potential difference between incentivized and non-incentivized participants. For the effort task it will be compared how many matrices consisting of 100 randomly generated zeros and ones the participants were able to count properly within 15 minutes. 50 matrices will be provided. For the creativity task it will be compared how many insight problems that require unorthodox thinking the participants were able to solve correctly. 5 questions will be provided with 3 minutes for each insight problem. The participants will work on the tasks in intervals to prevent order effects. This means they work for 3 minutes on a creativity task, then they count matrices for 3 minutes, followed by another creativity task, and so on.

Added to the outlined treatment variables demographics, attitudes of overconfidence, task enjoyment and self-assessment will be collected with a questionnaire as control measures and for explorative analysis.

he payment regime will be the independent variable while the respective outcome in the task will be the dependent variable. For the first two hypotheses a t-test and a Mann-Whitney-U-test will be executed to investigate for each of the two treatment groups whether the results are significantly different from each other. For the third hypothesis it will be evaluated whether the results for the effort task and the results for the creative task correlate. A simple OLS regression will be executed where creative score is the dependent variable and the effort score is the independent variable. The regression will also control for the treatment variable. We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining significance.

q24.value: We check whether certain demographic traits may be related to the outcomes. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables like gender and the outcomes. Moreover,  overconfidence, task enjoyment and self-assessment will also be evaluated for potential relationships with the outcome.

q1.value: Antisocial Empathy, Morality + Harm, Intergroup Aggression

q2.value: Emily Lasko, David Chester, Kurt Gray, Chelsea Schein

q3.value:
This study contains three distinct projects:
1. Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy
2. Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm
3. Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression

---------Project 1: Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
Aggressive behaviors inflict massive costs on public health. Psychopathy — the tendency to be callous, manipulative, and lack remorse — is one of the most central predictors of aggression and a core feature of psychopathology. Psychopathic individuals’ antisocial acts have long been thought to be due to an inability to empathize with their victims. However, recent work suggests that psychopathic individuals have intact empathic abilities. Instead of employing their empathy to help others, psychopathic individuals appear to use empathy to exact greater harm on their victims. Antisocial empathy, its neural bases, and its effects on the aggression of psychopathic individuals all remain unexamined. Therefore, we have developed the following overarching research questions:

Research Question 1A: Will psychopathic individuals exhibit accurate empathic processing when provided an antisocial motivation to do so?

Research Question 1B: What are the neural correlates of antisocial empathy among psychopathic individuals?

Research Question 1C: Will the link between psychopathy and aggression be mediated by antisocial empathy performance and the neural correlates thereof?

---------Project 2: Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------
A leading approach to understanding the psychological bases of human morality suggests that at the core of moral judgments are perceptions of harm. More specifically, when individuals seek to determine whether an action is immoral or not, they are actually attempting to identify the extent to which that action is harmful. However, other theoretical approaches challenge this harm-based account of morality. To empirically test the accuracy of this harm-based approach, we have developed the following research question.

Research Question 2. Does the brain (the medial prefrontal cortex, specifically) exhibit similar patterns of functional representation during judgments of immorality, as compared to judgments of harm?

---------Project 3: Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
The neural correlates of social rejection and aggression are under continuous investigation. However, the neural responses to the social phenomenon have been rarely studied in an intergroup context.  To better understand this, we asked the following research questions:

Research Question 3A: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggression is directed at an ingroup or an outgroup target?

Research Question 3B: Do neural correlates of provocation differ depending on whether the source of the provocation is an ingroup or an outgroup member?

Research Question 3C: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggressor has recently been socially-rejected by the outgroup (versus an ingroup) target?

Research Question 3D: Do neural correlates of rejection via outgroup members correspond to altered patterns of brain activity during subsequent retaliation against that outgroup?

q4.value:
---------Project 1: Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
Research Question 1A: Will psychopathic individuals exhibit empathic processing when provided an antisocial motivation to do so?

H1: When empathy facilitates an antisocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will positively correlate with ratings of others’ pain.

H2: When empathy facilitates a prosocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will negatively correlate with ratings of others’ pain.

Research Question 1B: What are the neural correlates of antisocial empathy among psychopathic individuals?

H3: When empathy facilitates an antisocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will be positively correlated with activation of empathic brain regions (ventrolateral prefrontal cortex [VLPFC], posterior cingulate cortex [PCC], temporoparietal junction [TPJ], ventromedial prefrontal cortex [VMPFC])  while viewing others’ pain.

H4: When empathy facilitates a prosocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will be negatively correlated with activation of empathic brain regions (VLPFC, PCC, TPJ, VMPFC) while viewing others’ pain.

Research Question 1C: Will the link between psychopathy and aggression be mediated by antisocial empathy and the neural correlates thereof?

H5: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will be mediated by greater empathic pain ratings when motivated by antisocial goals.

H6: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will not be mediated by greater empathic pain ratings when motivated by prosocial goals.

H7: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will be mediated by greater recruitment of empathic brain regions while viewing others’ pain, when motivated by antisocial goals.

H8: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will not be mediated by greater recruitment of empathic brain regions while viewing others’ pain, when motivated by prosocial goals.

---------Project 2: Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------

Research Question 2. Does the brain (the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex, specifically) exhibit similar patterns of functional representation during judgments of immorality, as compared to judgments of harm?

H9: The dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC) will exhibit greater functional, representation similarity between immorality and harm judgments, than between immorality and judgments of:
A: intentionality
B: disgust
C: unpleasantness
D: weirdness

---------Project 3: Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
Research Question 3A: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggression is directed at an ingroup or an outgroup target?

H10: Outgroup aggression (> ingroup aggression) will be associated with greater activity in brain regions representing reward (ventral striatum) and interpersonal unfamiliarity (DMPFC).

H11: Outgroup aggression (> ingroup aggression) will be associated with less activity in brain regions representing inhibitory and cognitive control (VLPFC, dorsolateral PFC), interpersonal closeness (VMPFC), and painful conflict (dorsal anterior cingulate cortex [DACC]).

Research Question 3B: Do neural correlates of provocation differ depending on whether the source of the provocation is an ingroup or an outgroup member?

H12: Outgroup provocation (> ingroup provocation) will be associated with greater activity in brain regions representing angry rumination (DMPFC) and painful conflict (DACC).

Research Question 3C: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggressor has recently been socially-rejected by the outgroup (versus an ingroup) target?

H13: Post-rejection aggression (> pre-rejection aggression) will be associated with greater activity in brain regions representing angry rumination (DMPFC) and painful conflict (anterior insula, DACC).

Research Question 3D: Do neural correlates of rejection via outgroup members correspond to altered patterns of brain activity during subsequent retaliation against that outgroup?

H14: Greater activity in brain regions representing reward (ventral striatum) during post-rejection outgroup aggression (versus post-rejection ingroup aggression) will mediate the positive effect of rejection-related activity in brain regions that represent painful conflict (anterior insula, DACC) on post-rejection outgroup aggression (i.e., noise blasts) from the MRI Aggression Task.

---------Project 1. Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
This project will adopt a 2 (within-participants; antisocial versus prosocial empathy conditions) x continuous (between--participants: primary psychopathy scores).

---------Project 2. Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------
This project will entail a 6-condition (within-participants; immoral versus harmful versus intentional versus disgust versus unpleasant versus weird judgment-type) main effect design.

---------Project 3. Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
This project will adopt a 2 (within-participants; outgroup versus ingroup aggression) x 2 (within-participants: pre versus post-rejection) design.

q9.value:
---------Project 1. Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
The order of the antisocial and prosocial blocks of empathy trials are randomly-determined for each participant by the task presentation software. 

---------Project 2. Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------
The order of moral scenarios and their associated judgment-types are both randomly-determined for each participant by the task presentation software. 

---------Project 3. Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
The following variables will be randomly-determined for each participant by the task presentation software:
-opponent provocation settings
-wins/losses
-outgroup versus ingroup trials

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Data collection is ongoing at the time of this preregistration, the data have not yet been accessed outside of preliminary data quality checks.

question.value:
We will recruit male participants (N = 46) from the Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) campus and the surrounding Richmond, VA community via the SONA system and recruitment flyers placed in high traffic areas (e.g., residences, cafes). Participants will be selected using the following criteria:
1) Males aged 18 – 35 years of age
2) Biological sex and gender identity = male
3) English speaking (will not be advertised but screened)
4) No current or regular use of prescribed or illicit psychoactive drugs
5) Free of major health problems (e.g., diabetes, HIV, Parkinson's disease)
6) Free of a neurological or psychiatric disorders
7) No current drug abuse (e.g., recreational drug use, average alcohol intake in excess of 4 drinks per day).
8) VCU undergraduate students
9) Right hand dominant
10) Free of claustrophobia
11) Absent MRI risk factors (e.g., implanted medical device, body mass index < 35, braces)
12) Free of medical conditions that render individuals with overly sensitive hearing
13) No colorblindness

Participants will be compensated with either course credit or monetary compensation.

q14.value: This sample size is determined purely by the amount of funds available for this particular project. Once the funds are depleted, data collection will cease.

q15.value: We will stop data collection when we have depleted our funding.

question.value:
---------Project 1. Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
Participants will view face images of people in varying degrees of physical pain (acquired from the Delaware Pain Dataset) in response to several aversive stimuli (shock, heat, cold, poke) and then rate the degree of pain they believe that target is experiencing in the image from 1 (low) to 4 (high). To manipulate whether such empathic processing is antisocially- or prosocially-motivated, participants are informed prior to the task that they are part of a team of VCU students who are completing the study in competition with a team of students from the rival school (University of Richmond [UofR]). Participants are instructed that they will view members of their own team and the opposing team in varying levels of pain and that they will use these images (ad the ratings of them they provide) to determine which types of aversive stimuli to apply (shock, heat, cold, poke) to their opponents for maximal pain infliction and to their team-mates for minimal pain infliction. In the pain rating task, participants viewed 5 VCU targets and 5 UofR targets. They viewed each target 4 times, in varying states of pain that were paired with one of the four fictitious sources of pain (shock, heat, cold, poke). This resulted in a total of 20 antisocial empathy (i.e., UofR) trials and 20 prosocial empathy (i.e., VCU) trials, which were lumped into 2 blocks --- one block containing 20 trials of one empathy-type. The order of these blocks were randomly determined. Within each block, the order of the 20 trials will be randomly determined by the computer for each participant.

---------Project 2. Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------
Participants will read 25 scenarios with morality-relevant content that were piloted to be characterized by the scenario's accidental, disgusting, weird, purity-focused, or harmful nature (5 scenarios per scenario-type). The order of the scenarios is randomly-determined by the computer for each participant. Each scenario will be judged along 4 criteria, randomly-selected from 6 possible judgment-types (harmful, immoral, intentional, gross, unpleasant, weird). This resulted in 100 total judgments (~16-17 trials per judgment-type, with some variation from participant to participant). 

---------Project 3. Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
Participants will complete an aggression task against either an ingroup opponent (i.e., a VCU student) or an outgroup opponent (i.e., a UofR student). The task will consist of 2 ingroup and 2 outgroup blocks, each block consisting of 8 trials (16 ingroup aggression trials total, 16 outgroup aggression trials total). The order of the 4 blocks will be randomly determined by the computer for each participant.

Then, participants will complete the Cyberball task, which they play with 2 outgroup partners (i.e., 2 UofR students) --- 1 of these outgroup members was their opponent in the first aggression task and the other outgroup member is a new interaction partner. In the first 2 blocks of the game, they are included by their outgroup partners (i.e., they receive an equal number of ball-tosses), yet in the third block, after 30 seconds of inclusion, participants are excluded by their outgroup opponents for ~50 seconds. The temporal sequence of this inclusion-then-exclusion manipulation is fixed across participants.

Participants will then complete the aggression task again, against the same opponent from the first aggression task and who just excluded them in the Cyberball task. This second run of the aggression task follows the same manipulation procedures as detailed above.

Across all three projects, we will measure whole-brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) during each task.

---------Project 1. Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
1. Pain ratings (1 [low] - 4 [high]), averaged separately for antisocial and prosocial empathy trials.
2. Psychopathy predictor variables: Self-Report Psychopathy Scale (SRP-III; Primary Psychopathy = average of Interpersonal and Affect subscales; Secondary Psychopathy = average of Lifestyle and Antisocial subscales)
3. Self-reported moderators, calculated by averaging items:
-the Cognitive Empathy, Affective Resonance, and Affective Dissonance subscales of the Affective and Cognitive Empathy Measure
-the Perspective Taking, Empathic Concern, Personal Distress subscales of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index
-Parochial Empathy Scale
-the Boldness, Meanness, and Disinhibition subscales of the Triarchic Psychopathy Model Scale

---------Project 2. Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------
1. Moral judgment ratings (1 [not at all] - 4 [extremely]), averaged separately for each of the 6 judgment-types (harmful, immoral, intentional, gross, unpleasant, weird).
2. Self-reported moderators, calculated by averaging items:
-the Moral Self subscale of the Moral Identity Questionnaire
-the Harm subscale of the Moral Foundations Questionnaire

---------Project 3. Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
1. Volume settings for noise blasts directed at participants' opponents (1 [low] - 4 [high]) from both runs of the MRI Aggression Paradigm, averaged separately by whether the target of the noise blast was an ingroup/outgroup member and by run.
2. Exclusion manipulation check: all 22 non-affect items of the Need Threat Scale + the % ball-tosses-received measure.
3. Reverse inference check: Aggressive Pleasure Scale
4. Self-reported moderators, calculated by averaging items:
-Short Sadistic Impulse Scale
-the Anger Expression Out subscale of the Angry Mood Improvement Inventory
-the Physical Aggression subscale of the Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire
-Identity Fusion Scale
All self-report scale indices will be computed by reverse-scoring appropriate items and then averaging across the relevant items.

---------Project 1. Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
H1-2: We will average pain rating within the trials of the antisocial and prosocial empathy conditions and compare them using paired-samples t-tests.

H3-4:
A. fMRI Data Preprocessing:
The Oxford Center for Functional MRI of the Brain’s Software Library (FSL version 6.0) will be used to conduct all preprocessing and fMRI analyses. Reconstructed functional volumes will undergo head motion correction to the median functional volume using FSL’s MCFLIRT tool. FSL’s Brain Extraction Tool will be used to remove non-brain tissue from all functional and structural volumes. After a series of data quality checks, functional volumes will undergo interleaved slice-timing correction, pre-whitening, spatial smoothing (using a 5mm full-width-half-maximum Gaussian kernel), and temporal high-pass filtering (100s cutoff). These processed brain volumes will be fed into subsequent data analyses.

B. fMRI Data Analysis:
Preprocessed fMRI data will be analyzed using two-level general linear
modeling. 

The first level (within-participants). Participants’ whole-brain functional volumes from each run of the empathy rating task will be entered into a fixed-effects general linear model (GLM) that will model events using a canonical double-gamma hemodynamic response function with a temporal derivative. Regressors-of-interest for the empathy rating task will include antisocial empathy pain viewing, antisocial empathy pain rating, prosocial empathy pain viewing, and prosocial empathy pain rating. Pain rating trials will be modeled by both a parametrically-modulated regressor (that is weighted by the 1-4 rating provided by the participant for that trial) and a non-modulated regressor. Six head motion parameters will also be included as nuisance regressors. Six linear contrasts will model each of these six regressors compared to the implicit, un-modeled baseline. Then, two additional contrasts will model antisocial > prosocial empathy pain viewing and antisocial > prosocial empathy pain rating (parametrically-modulated). 

Second-level (across-participants). Each of participants’ 8 contrast maps from the second
level will be fed into a group level, mixed-effects GLM that creates whole-brain
group average maps for each contrast. In addition to these aggregated group masks, this GLM will also model each participant’s primary psychopathy scores from the SRP-III as a continuous, whole-brain regressor and will create aggregated group masks for these regression analyses as well. Cluster-based, family-wise error-rate (FWER) correction
using Gaussian random field theory will then be applied to each of these 16, group contrast maps using a cluster identification threshold of Z > 2.3. Clusters will be retained that pass a significance threshold of p < .05. 

These group-level analyses will be repeated using an 'empathy network' region-of-interest (ROI) mask that includes the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (DACC), bilateral anterior insula, VLPFC, VMPFC, and PCC. The DACC and anterior insula masks will be acquired from previous research (Chester et al., 2018). The remaining masks will be acquired from the AAL atlas (VLPFC = orbital + opercular + triangularis aspects of the inferior frontal gyrus mask; VMPFC = medial aspect of the orbital gyrus mask; PCC = posterior cingulate mask).

Chester, D. S., Lynam, D. R., Milich, R., & DeWall, C. N. (2018). Neural mechanisms of the rejection–aggression link. Social cognitive and affective neuroscience, 13(5), 501-512.

H5-6:
Pain ratings from the antisocial condition will be entered into a mediation model as the mediator of the effect of primary psychopathy on aggressive behavior (as measured by the Physical Aggression subscale of the Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire). Pain ratings from the prosocial condition will be modeled as a covariate upon both the dependent and mediating variables. The PROCESS macro version 3.2 for SPSS will be used to conduct nonparametric bootstrapping (using 5,000 bootstrapped resamples) to test the significance of this neural mechanism’s indirect effect.

H7-8:
We will extract antisocial-empathy-related (antisocial > prosocial pain viewing) brain activity estimates (in the form of % BOLD signal change values) from the empathy network ROI. These estimates will be entered into a mediation model, as the mediator of the effect of primary psychopathy on aggressive behavior (as measured by the Physical Aggression subscale of the Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire). The PROCESS macro version 3.2 for SPSS will be used to conduct nonparametric bootstrapping (using 5,000 bootstrapped resamples) to test the significance of this neural mechanism’s indirect effect.

---------Project 2. Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------

H9-Representational Similarity Analyses:
fMRI data preprocessing and analysis will unfold in an identical manner to Project 1, excepting that the within-participants, first-level GLM will include a regressor-of-interest for each of the 6 judgment types (Harm Judgments, Immoral Judgments, Weird Judgments, Disgust Judgments, Intentional Judgments, Unpleasant Judgments; and nuisance regressors that capture moral scenario trials and head motion). Linear contrasts will model each of the 6 judgment-types against the implicit baseline. From these whole-brain Z-statistic contrast maps, we will extract a matrix that represents the pattern of activity for each judgment-type across the voxels of the DMPFC ROI (each row represents a judgment-type and each column represents a DMPFC voxel). At each DMPFC voxel, pairwise comparisons (calculated in the form of correlation distance) will compare each judgment-type to the other 5 judgment-types to create a Representational Dissimilarity Matrix (RDM) that is specific to that voxel. We will then aggregate RDMs across the voxels of the DMPFC. The DMPFC ROI will be determined by both fall within the AAL atlas' superior frontal gyrus mask *and* are identified by the Neurosynth meta-analytic results for the term 'moral'. 

We will then aggregate these 6 RDMs across participants, creating a 6x6 RDM that compares each judgment-type to each other judgment-type, from which we will draw our inferences by computing a Fisher's Z transformation of the associations at each cell of the RDM and computing a one-sample t-test against 0 for each cell and using the following online utility to examine whether the correlations are significantly different from one another: http://quantpsy.org/corrtest/corrtest2.htm

To conduct these RSA models, we will modify the Python/R code publicly-provided here: https://github.com/markallenthornton/MIND18_RSA_tutorial/blob/master/Representational_similarity_analysis.Rmd

---------Project 3. Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
H10-13:
A. MRI Aggression Tasks
fMRI data preprocessing and analysis will unfold in an identical manner to Project 1, excepting that the first-level, within-participants-within-run GLM will include regressors-of-interest for Outgroup Aggression, Ingroup Aggression, Outgroup Provocation (parametrically-modulated), Ingroup Provocation (parametrically-modulated), Outgroup Provocation (non-parametrically-modulated), and Ingroup Provocation (non-parametrically-modulated); and nuisance regressors that capture Wins, Losses, Competitions, and head motion). Linear contrasts will model each of the 6 regressors-of-interest against the implicit baseline, as well as Outgroup > Ingroup Aggression and Outgroup > Ingroup Provocation (parametrically-modulated). This GLM will be run separately for the pre-rejection and post-rejection runs for each participant.

A second-level, within-participants-across-runs GLM will combine the pre-rejection and post-rejection runs, modeling each run separately, combined, and contrasting Post-Rejection > Pre-Rejection. 

A series of third-level, across-participants GLM will create group contrast maps for (A) the first-level pre-rejection GLM, (B) the first-level post-rejection GLM, and (C) the combined, second-level post-rejection + pre-rejection runs.

B. Cyberball Task
A first-level, within-participants GLM will include two regressors-of-interest for the Accept and Reject blocks, and then regressors for the 'Get Ready' trials and head motion. Linear contrasts will compare Reject > Accept. A second-level GLM aggregated these contrasts maps across participants and across the entire brain.

H14-Mediation modeling:
We will extract rejection-related (reject > accept) brain activity estimates (in the form of % BOLD signal change values) from the DACC and anterior insula ROIs. We will also extract outgroup-aggression-related (outgroup > ingroup aggression) from both the pre-rejection and post-rejection runs of the MRI Aggression Task using significant clusters identified in the univariate whole-brain approach.  These outgroup-aggression-related activity estimates will be entered into a mediation model as the mediator of the effect of rejection-related DACC/insula activity on aggressive behavior (as measured by the outgroup-directed noise blasts from the post-rejection run of the MRI aggression task). Pre-rejection outgroup-aggression-related activity will be modeled as a covariate upon the dependent and mediating variables. The PROCESS macro version 3.2 for SPSS will be used to conduct nonparametric bootstrapping (using 5,000 bootstrapped resamples) to test the significance of this neural mechanism’s indirect effect.

q24.value:
---------Project 2: Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------
It may be that judgments of harm are most similar to judgments of immorality when they are combined with judgments of intentionality, as harm is often perceived as immoral to the extent it is perceived as intentional. As such, we will conduct an exploratory analysis that compares the representational similarity of harm + intentional judgments to immorality judgments, expecting that this combined form of judgments will exhibit more DMPFC activation similarity to immoral judgments than the following judgment-types:
A: disgust
B: unpleasantness
C: weirdness

Additionally, negative valence may also be a critical factor in the similarity between harm and immorality. As such, we will conduct an exploratory analysis that compares the representational similarity of harm + intentional + unpleasant judgments to immorality judgments, expecting that this combined form of judgments will exhibit more DMPFC activation similarity to immoral judgments than the following judgment-types:
A: disgust
B: weirdness

registration_responses.q1: Antisocial Empathy, Morality + Harm, Intergroup Aggression
registration_responses.q2: Emily Lasko, David Chester, Kurt Gray, Chelsea Schein
registration_responses.q3:
This study contains three distinct projects:
1. Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy
2. Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm
3. Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression

---------Project 1: Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
Aggressive behaviors inflict massive costs on public health. Psychopathy — the tendency to be callous, manipulative, and lack remorse — is one of the most central predictors of aggression and a core feature of psychopathology. Psychopathic individuals’ antisocial acts have long been thought to be due to an inability to empathize with their victims. However, recent work suggests that psychopathic individuals have intact empathic abilities. Instead of employing their empathy to help others, psychopathic individuals appear to use empathy to exact greater harm on their victims. Antisocial empathy, its neural bases, and its effects on the aggression of psychopathic individuals all remain unexamined. Therefore, we have developed the following overarching research questions:

Research Question 1A: Will psychopathic individuals exhibit accurate empathic processing when provided an antisocial motivation to do so?

Research Question 1B: What are the neural correlates of antisocial empathy among psychopathic individuals?

Research Question 1C: Will the link between psychopathy and aggression be mediated by antisocial empathy performance and the neural correlates thereof?

---------Project 2: Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------
A leading approach to understanding the psychological bases of human morality suggests that at the core of moral judgments are perceptions of harm. More specifically, when individuals seek to determine whether an action is immoral or not, they are actually attempting to identify the extent to which that action is harmful. However, other theoretical approaches challenge this harm-based account of morality. To empirically test the accuracy of this harm-based approach, we have developed the following research question.

Research Question 2. Does the brain (the medial prefrontal cortex, specifically) exhibit similar patterns of functional representation during judgments of immorality, as compared to judgments of harm?

---------Project 3: Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
The neural correlates of social rejection and aggression are under continuous investigation. However, the neural responses to the social phenomenon have been rarely studied in an intergroup context.  To better understand this, we asked the following research questions:

Research Question 3A: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggression is directed at an ingroup or an outgroup target?

Research Question 3B: Do neural correlates of provocation differ depending on whether the source of the provocation is an ingroup or an outgroup member?

Research Question 3C: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggressor has recently been socially-rejected by the outgroup (versus an ingroup) target?

Research Question 3D: Do neural correlates of rejection via outgroup members correspond to altered patterns of brain activity during subsequent retaliation against that outgroup?
registration_responses.q4:
---------Project 1: Psychopathy and the Neural Bases of Antisocial Empathy---------
Research Question 1A: Will psychopathic individuals exhibit empathic processing when provided an antisocial motivation to do so?

H1: When empathy facilitates an antisocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will positively correlate with ratings of others’ pain.

H2: When empathy facilitates a prosocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will negatively correlate with ratings of others’ pain.

Research Question 1B: What are the neural correlates of antisocial empathy among psychopathic individuals?

H3: When empathy facilitates an antisocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will be positively correlated with activation of empathic brain regions (ventrolateral prefrontal cortex [VLPFC], posterior cingulate cortex [PCC], temporoparietal junction [TPJ], ventromedial prefrontal cortex [VMPFC])  while viewing others’ pain.

H4: When empathy facilitates a prosocial goal, primary psychopathic traits will be negatively correlated with activation of empathic brain regions (VLPFC, PCC, TPJ, VMPFC) while viewing others’ pain.

Research Question 1C: Will the link between psychopathy and aggression be mediated by antisocial empathy and the neural correlates thereof?

H5: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will be mediated by greater empathic pain ratings when motivated by antisocial goals.

H6: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will not be mediated by greater empathic pain ratings when motivated by prosocial goals.

H7: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will be mediated by greater recruitment of empathic brain regions while viewing others’ pain, when motivated by antisocial goals.

H8: The positive correlation between primary psychopathic traits and aggressive behavior will not be mediated by greater recruitment of empathic brain regions while viewing others’ pain, when motivated by prosocial goals.

---------Project 2: Neural Representational Similarity in Judgments of Morality and Harm---------

Research Question 2. Does the brain (the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex, specifically) exhibit similar patterns of functional representation during judgments of immorality, as compared to judgments of harm?

H9: The dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC) will exhibit greater functional, representation similarity between immorality and harm judgments, than between immorality and judgments of:
A: intentionality
B: disgust
C: unpleasantness
D: weirdness

---------Project 3: Neural Correlates of Intergroup Rejection and Aggression---------
Research Question 3A: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggression is directed at an ingroup or an outgroup target?

H10: Outgroup aggression (> ingroup aggression) will be associated with greater activity in brain regions representing reward (ventral striatum) and interpersonal unfamiliarity (DMPFC).

H11: Outgroup aggression (> ingroup aggression) will be associated with less activity in brain regions representing inhibitory and cognitive control (VLPFC, dorsolateral PFC), interpersonal closeness (VMPFC), and painful conflict (dorsal anterior cingulate cortex [DACC]).

Research Question 3B: Do neural correlates of provocation differ depending on whether the source of the provocation is an ingroup or an outgroup member?

H12: Outgroup provocation (> ingroup provocation) will be associated with greater activity in brain regions representing angry rumination (DMPFC) and painful conflict (DACC).

Research Question 3C: Do neural correlates of aggression differ depending on whether the aggressor has recently been socially-rejected by the outgroup (versus an ingroup) target?

H13: Post-rejection aggression (> pre-rejection aggression) will be associated with greater activity in brain regions representing angry rumination (DMPFC) and painful conflict (anterior insula, DACC).

Research Question 3D: Do neural correlates of rejection via outgroup members correspond to altered patterns of brain activity during subsequent retaliation against that outgroup?

H14: Greater activity in brain regions representing reward (ventral striatum) during post-rejection outgroup aggression (versus post-rejection ingroup aggression) will mediate the positive effect of rejection-related activity in brain regions that represent painful conflict (anterior insula, DACC) on post-rejection outgroup aggression (i.e., noise blasts) from the MRI Aggression Task.
